posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2364600
A good sample itinerary would be:
Madrid with daytrips to Toledo and/or Siguenza (5 days total). After those daytrips, come back to Madrid by train and fly to Barcelona (3 days). Rent a car for a day and drive up to Peniscola or find a train down to Valencia and drive down/get a bus along the coast to Alicante. Airport from alicante to Sevilla. Then rent a car and do Sevilla > Jerez de la Frontera > Cadiz > Marbella > Malaga > train to Cordoba > back to sevilla for easy flight to Madrid to go home.

It's a bit extended but you can certainly cut things out and rearrange. It's an overall great tour of Spain with tons to see and do, most of which wont require you to rent a car either.

What? Do you have a license? If yes, if you're from the US or Europe, you just need to show your license at the rental place.
Parking is generally terrible in crowded cities, best way to do is to park outside the city (example: there's a big parking outside of Toledo).
I was in Trujillo in winter though, and the locals even asked me to park in front of their home. It's mostly fine in not overcrowded cities.

General rule for a medium to large size city in Europe is to park your car ASAP either at the hotel's parking (prices can go from for free to quite expensive but at least it makes your trip easier), or some public parking near your hotel (expensive) or outside of the city (cheap).

Anywhere else like villages, it's easy as fuck to park and it's mostly free.

posts.name: Walking Tanzanian
posts.com:
So I'm thinking of leaving tomorrow and trek through my country, Tanzania. Any advice on cross-country walking? I'll leave my phone and everything behind. Carry a backpack and a few clothes and some things to lie on and cover myself, a container for food I buy along the way, and a 2 Litre bottle of water. I'll post a don't worry message on Twitter, and have about $2000 in my bank account(which is a lot in Tanzania) and will be withdrawing little by little at ATMs.

Why am I doing this? After my last suicide attempt life has been feeling pointless. I dropped out of university and have been blaming myself for not making the suicide work. I always believe the universe is so big, you can choose to minimize your gaze and focus on the little you can control, or expand your horizons and explore. I've done the former for so long and it hasn't left me satisfied, might as well try the latter for a change. I hope in this journey I find a reason to live, or a reason not to, but regardless, I owe myself to try.

I'm currently in Bukoba(picrel), I'm thinking of following the paved trunk roads and sleeping alongside it all the way to Dar es salaam. I'll try to stay at most 2 days without food before I consider taking a small bus to the closest town.

Anyway. Any advice on cross-country walking?

>>2359793
I have like a 2.2 liter water bladder for when I bicycle or go hiking that can be stuffed into a hiking or cycling backpack. I would take something like that and an extra 1 litter bottle for the side pocket of your backpack.

If you don't eat for a day, your body runs out of glycogen used to fuel your muscles, cells, brain, etc. When that happens you go into ketosis and burn fat to continue on. But the ketosis process is unpleasant and it will fog your brain, your muscular endurance will be less, etc. Everytime I get really sick and don't want to eat like when I had covid and the attendant pneumonia or bronchitis(years ago), I go into ketosis and I feel like crap just sitting on my ass. Sure you can hike in that state, but you will be miserable and make much less progress than if you eat constantly. You also need to eat before you get really really hungry, I learned that from cycling. By the time you are too hungry you already burned out the glyocen in your muscles and your fatigue level will greatly increase and your muscular endurance will decrease. So your pace will drop to a crawl. Eating after your glyocen dumps won't help much either, you will need to rest for hours before you recover.

Here's my minimalist packing kit for trekking in the African countryside:
-Water filter
-Chlorine tablets (or bleach, or iodine) for treating water
-Mosquito net, and/or hammock
-Hat or headscarf
-Small pot for cooking/making tea/sterilizing water (tea/coffee is very important for morale)
-2 cups (in case you have a guest at camp)
-Bathroom kit including tissues
-Kit for treating blisters and cuts
-Needle and thread
-Pen and notebook
-Musical instrument (I carry a kashaka, sometimes a harmonica)

2L of water might be enough, but 3 is much safer. You won't die of thirst, but you'll have a shitty day if you run out of water.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The five ex-Soviet "Stans" aren't as much talked about as other destinations despite offering a lot to visitors.
I have lived and travelled through them, so let me give you an overview in case you're interested.

posts.name: Kazakhstan
posts.com:
The biggest of five countries and also the country with subjectively the least number of obvious tourist attractions.
What makes up for it is the sheer size of the country, you can spend days going across by train and experience the diversity of landscapes from snow-capped mountains, empty steppe to plain old desert.

The big split is between North and South, with the less-visited North featuring the Dubai-esque capital Astana (formerly Nur-Sultan, formerly Astana) and the "Russian" provinces and the Karaganda desert, the South having multiple historical cities dotted along the border.

Most people will visit Almaty, the most successful example of a modernised Soviet city and also the only place where you can eat at western fast-food chains that aren't KFC for a change.
Near Almaty you can find a lot of mountainous nature such as the Big Almaty Lake (pic related), valleys and nature parks towards China but also a glimpse into China at the Khorgos Special Economic Zone where duty is charged by the kilo.
Almaty and Bishkek in Kyrgyzstan are 4 hours and about 10 dollars apart by car, you can easily fly into either city and reach the other on the same day.

A underrated place is the South-West: On the way from or to Uzbekistan you can make a detour for a day trip to newly-renovated Turkestan and Taraz is also worth stopping over for a couple hours.
The highway between Almaty and Shymkent is a racetrack, especially at night, so if you want to keep your nerves just use one of the frequent trains.

Western Kazakhstan is partially located in Europe and can be used as a starting point towards the Caucasus and Russia by low-cost carrier and frequent overnight trains.
On the way you will pass Baikonur, sadly only legally accessible through overpriced tours, launches can be seen from outside, sneaking in can be risky, especially in the current political climate.

posts.name: Kyrgyzstan
posts.com:
The "Switzerland of Central Asia" has the most liberal visa regime, most Westerners will be able to stay for 60 days without any visa or other bureaucratic hurdles.

Everybody will pass through Bishkek, the poorer, more "Soviet" cousin of Almaty, especially if you need a visa for any neighbouring country.
The city itself can be visited in a day, two if you're interested in bazars, Alamedin, Dordoi and Osh bazar being the ones recommended for a comprehensive experience.
The city may be boring to visit but is very comfortable to live due to low price levels and everything a second world dweller being in walking distance.

The main draw of Kyrgyzstan is the nature, be it the surprisingly good ski resort near Karakol, the never-freezing Issyk-Kul, the countless valleys featuring yurts and hot springs, the mountain passes towards the South and the changed Kyrgyz part of the Fergana valley.
If you are fine with not being spoken to in English you can get nature excursions for low, be it guided hikes, ski transfers to yurt stays with optional horse riding.
Try to get excursions with meals prepared by locals, during summer you will usually get loads of fresh vegetables and fruits to complement the meat-laden main dishes.

posts.name: Tajikistan
posts.com:
The non-Turk outlier of the region that is heavily influenced by Persian culture has become more open recently, with most westerners being able to enter visa-free for 30 days.
You still need to get a separate permit to visit the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonmous Oblast, but you should be able to get it on the way in Dushanbe.

Despite being the poorest country (salary-wise), as a tourist you end up spending more money than in neighbouring Kyrgyzstan, be it on transport, accommodation or imported goods.

Tajikistan has some dishes that you cannot find in the surrounding countries, a blessing if you have been in rural areas for a while and are getting tired of plov, samsas and noodles.
Many expats say that Dushanbe feels a bit like Pyongyang, with police checking beards and headwear to prevent extremism from taking root and the limited number of places to go after work where you will end up meeting the same people anyway.

If you're in Tashkent for more than two days and getting bored you can do an overnight trip to Khujand across the border to see what the city would have looked like before the reconstructions.

Because of the border conflict and other border closures you will not be able to enter Kyrgyzstan without taking a detour via Uzbekistan, easy to do from Khujand or Dushanbe, more annoying when you're deep in the GBAO.

posts.name: Turkmenistan
posts.com:
There are two way to see Turkmenistan, the expensive and comprehensive way using a North Korea style tour with a guide and driver or by rushing through the country on a transit visa between Iran and Uzbekistan.
If on a tour everything will be taken care of, just pay the amount requested and enjoy the ride.
If you successfully managed to get a transit visa then you will spend your time and cash moving between towns in trains and shared taxis with locals, haggling with hotels for low rates, bribing officials with dollars and cigarettes (which seem to have become more and more valuable in the last year, an open pack can save you queues and inspections without much suspicion.

The most popular transit visa route is between Urgench/Khiva and Mashad, within three days you can see unique nature (pic related), a historical city and the shiny marble capital.

posts.name: Uzbekistan
posts.com:
In the "Big Three" cities of Samarkand/Bukhara/Khiva you will find the closes to mass tourism, with European boomers spending their retirement money on souvenirs to bring back to their boomer friends.
Still, it's nowhere near the levels of any European tourist city, even at the most popular sites you can just wait five minutes and you'll be only be sharing it with domestic tourists and local touts.

While the Big Three are what draw the most people, on a longer visit you may want to check out more nature-based destinations such as Karakalpakstan, site of what used to be the Aral Sea or the Fergana Valley where the above-mentiond souvenirs are actually made.

Moving between regions can be done by train or by domestic flight via Tashkent.
While the flights are comfortable and not too expensive, you can save money and experience authentic Uzbekistan by taking an overnight train, especially if you book third class (platzkart). If you find out that the experience is too authentic for you, you can easily bribe the conductor to find you a private compartment for about 10 to 15 dollars.

While Tashkent might be your entry point, you will quickly find out that it's a fairly boring city, especially the nightlife when compared to Almaty and Bishkek.
Sadly for the inclined tourist there are less and less Soviet-era buildings left untouched in Tashkent, but a simple trip to any neighbouring country will satisfy your cravings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you definitely need are some skills reading Cyrillic, even in countries that formally switched to Roman characters.
With only English you won't get as far somebody who speaks just even basic Russian, English services are generally available but come at a premium.
Just using some basic greetings in the respective local languages will usually be met with enthusiasm, even if you then continue in Russian or pidgin English-Russian.

Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan are the two countries where you won't stand out as a white Westerner due to the high number of ethnic Russians, even at bazars you will get the same treatment as locals, at least until you open your mouth. Usually, this will work to your advantage, but be prepared to be talked to in Rapid Russian.

The region has a reputation of being dangerous, mostly due to the proximity to Afghanistan, but as a tourist the biggest risk you'll face is road traffic, some taxi rides will make even the most euphoric atheist pray for a safe journey.

In most cities you can save yourself a lot of trouble by installing the Yandex Taxi app, the local equivalent to Uber. Even just showing the app prices will give you stronger hand while haggling, never use a metered taxi without fixating a price first, it's an invitation to get ripped off.

Tourist SIM cards are available in every country, the easiest being in Kyrgyzstan where they'll just hand them out for free at busy border crossings, the most expensive being in Turkmenistan (and you may not be able to use shitpost on /int/), see the ever-useful Prepaid SIM Card Wiki for more details.

The best English internet site for this region is Caravanistan, some of the articles may become outdated but the forum will usually have the relevant updates.
I'll check this thread for questions and try to answer until this thread dies, so ask away!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>That being said, what’s the best time of the year to visit them?
You can visit all year around, but each region has its "best" season.
The desert parts of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and the whole of Turkmenistan are best visited in spring and autumn because it can get hot in summer, easily more than 40°C for days, although dry heat, so more bearable than similar humid destinations.
The mountain parts of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have their main season in summer when you can hike everywhere and all the summer facilities are open. In winter there are fewer places where you can go skiing and winter hiking, but in early spring and late autumn you'll find many places closed.
TL;DR: summer/winter for mountains, spring/autumn for the rest

>My russian is very very basic, will I survive?
Little Russian is already better than no Russian.
Learn some useful common phrases (e.g. Pimsleur Russian) and download an offline translator. Make sure that you have a Russian keyboard enabled in case somebody wants to translate to English.
I personally make sure to write down any amounts negotiated (especially taxi fares) on paper or on my phone and show them to prevent and misunderstandings or "misunderstandings" (i.e. scams).

>Lastly, what’s that flag chart?
It's the flags of the five countries crossed with each other!
You can see the original flags on the diagonal from top left to bottom right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>What would be the best order or “loop” to visit the stans?
If you have visa-free access to Uzbekistan I'd pass through there multiple times because you can get to all the other countries from there.
The KG-TJ border is closed and will likely remain closed for the time being, so Tajikistan is pretty much only accessible from Uzbekistan.
Having said that it's all a matter of preference and (time) budget.
If Turkmenistan opens (to how it used to be in 2019) I would enter from Iran on a transit visa via the Mashad-Ashgabat-Khiva route because that way you won't have to worry about carrying large amounts of cash afterwards.
From there I'd do the "Big Three" Khiva->Bukhara->Samarkand before crossing the border to Panjakent (TJ), going down to Dushanbe, the base for planning any activities in the GBAO.
The return from Dushanbe would be via Khujand to Tashkent, if you don't want to do the Anzob twice, you can also go via Termez, possible even by train.
From Tashkent you can either go North to see more desert/steppe in Kazakhstan or East to the Fergana valley, ending up in Osh (KG).
From there you can do the 10-hour ride to Bishkek, stopping over in Toktogul for a night if you want.
In Northern Kyrgyzstan, you will very likely spend some time in Issyk-Kul, both on the lake and the surrounding mountains, stopping over in Karakol before heading towards Almaty, easily reached via Bishkek, the more adventurous and scenic path via the Karakara valley.
From Almaty you can go West to Taraz/Shymkent/Turkestan for the Silk Road sights or North to Karaganda and Astana (not much to see but surprisingly cool during summer due it being very windy).

Obviously this is a very packed itinerary for a two-months, so you want to drop destinations and flesh out your stay at others.
You can do 4 out of 5 countries in less than 24 hours (by bus and taxi between Khujand TJ and Bishkek KG), but that's neither relaxing nor recommended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>Where would you spend most of your time?
It really depends on what you like:
Like mountains? Then you'll have the best time in Kyrgyzstan where you can spend months in the mountains if you desire.
Like history that isn't just rock carvings and shards? You'll be best served with Uzbekistan, both the "Big Three" and smaller destinations like the countless fortresses in the desert.

All countries but Turkmenistan give you ample time to visit and visa runs can be had for cheap.

It is really easy to go country collecting (my passport has pages and pages filled with entry and exit stamps due to extended weekend trips), but in the end you do not want to rush from one place to the next because of a tight itinerary.
Yes, you can visit Khiva/Bukhara in one day, but strolling through town in the late evening or early morning with nobody else in sight is something you can only do if you spend a night or two there.
The same can be said about chilling on the shores of Issyk-Kul or spending a lazy day in a yurt camp reading a book while listening to nature.

Anyway, let me know if you want to know more about a place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Food wise, how’s the food?
There's a reason why the region isn't a gourmet travel destination: The local dishes aren't much to write home about.
You'll have a lot of meat and grease and many dishes will start to feel similar after being here for some time.
The good thing is that the Soviet time brought foreign dishes that are now a staples of the local diet everywhere.
One of them are salads influenced by ethnic Koreans, available in all bazaars, most restaurants, delicatessen and supermarkets.
On a regular day, at least one of my meals contains whatever kind of salad I feel like that day. On bazaars they're usually home-made, sold by middle-aged women, most of them will let you try before buying, use that opportunity to sample, same applies for confectionery sold there.
I personally avoid "Pizza&Sushi" places, most of them don't do either right. Bigger cities have both proper pizzerias and sushi bars if you want to mix things up a little.

People are very proud of their bread (pic related), try to spot the differences between regions.
Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan have surprisingly good dairy products, just be aware that they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West.
Try whatever produce is in season, local fruits and vegetables are usually very tasty and fresh due to short supply chains. Again, they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West, probably because the local agriculture is less developed and therefore uses fewer modern preservatives.

If you're taking the train, take some vegetables, fruits and bread to share because the locals love to feed foreigners and see their reactions to local food and it's nice to be able to share as well.
Trains always have hot water, so instant noodles and mashed potatoes will be a safe backup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>What I can’t absolutely miss?
Try the "signature dishes" of the region like plov, lagman, beshparmak, manty, samsa.
Eat the ones you like again, preferably at small places, the shorter the menu, the better the dishes.

In Kyrgyzstan, especially in Issyk-Kul you have to try Ashlan-Fu (pic related), a Chinese-style cold noodle soup with vinegar (works very well for hangovers).
In Tajikistan you have to try Kurutob, a salad made from bread that for some reason you can't find in the neighbouring countries.
Don't forget about local minorities: Uyghurs and Dungans have some nice dishes, as have the ethnic Koreans that operate the Korean restaurants found in every bigger city.

If it's your first trip to the former USSR then you should definitely try what the other republics have to offer, be it Moldovan/Georgian/Azeri wine, Russian and Georgian cuisine or just plain old Ukrainian sweets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Also, is there a sim card that works in all of them?
It's cheaper and less hassle to buy a SIM card in each country than to see what roaming offers are available.
Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan can be annoying by requiring a hardware registration if you want to use a local SIM card for more than a month.
You can avoid that by roaming using a Kyrgyz SIM card, but that's too much of a hassle unless you're living in Kyrgyzstan, especially since you'll need to figure out the offers and how to top up from abroad if needed.
Roaming from abroad is usually expensive, the least expensive place for Europeans being Kazakhstan, in the rest of the region a local SIM card reigns supreme.
If you're just passing through Turkmenistan then you shouldn't waste your time hunting for a SIM card, if you're on a tour then your guide will be able to help you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370901
You're going to be spending some money - a budget tour of 4 days and 3 nights from a Western agency runs about 1000 dollars, for an additional 400 dollars you'll get 8 nights and 9 days in the country.
Obviously some local tour operator might be able to shave off some dollars from the quoted prices above, but most of the costs are set by the Turkmen government, so no getting around that.
This is the major reason why transit visa runs through the country are popular, you save money and have more (limited) freedom to choose your way through the country.

Any well-stocked tour agency can book you a tour to Turkmenistan, they all need to cooperate with some companies within the country that can issue the relevant invitation letters.
Have a look on the internet what interests you and get quotes from different companies, no need to pay more for the same service.
Caravanistan might start up their middleman services once the country opens and they get confirmations of things running again.

posts.name: Dylan
posts.sub: Is traveling really worth the hassle and cost?
posts.com:
Has anybody else become disillusioned with travel? Everyone shows off the glamorous side of traveling on social media when that's just a small part of the experience. Most of it is negative. There's the constant waiting, security checkpoints, boarding and deboarding packed planes, cramped seating with minimal legroom, surly flight attendants, long customs and immigration lines, currency exchange, language barriers, awkward situations and faux pas, hawkers persistently pestering you, corrupt police shaking you down, robbers targeting you as a tourist, food poisoning, motion sickness, uncomfortable weather that you aren't used to, crowds just about everywhere with 8 billion people on the planet. It's all so tiresome. Usually I need a vacation from my vacation when it's all over.

All for what? I can order all sorts of ethnic food in my city. I can date women from different cultural backgrounds here. I can use the internet or VR device to see the Eiffel Tower, Statue of Liberty and old dusty churches. I can visit museums virtually. I can learn about a country's history online. I can drive to beaches and nature. No need to travel across the globe for any of this. I wish I had realized this earlier in life before I wasted so much money on pointless travel. I would rather use the money towards a lakeside retreat home away from the city.

I have a degree in tourism.
It’s how we do travel that is all wrong.
People who say the world has never been more accessible are full of shit: access, to locations, products, services, transportation, etc is more restricted today than it has been at any other point in history.
This severely limits the kinds of experiences you can get from traveling, most people are railroaded into wasting their vacation on overpriced tourist traps.
The only way to get around is by being rich which gives you access to so many more things.
We desperately need a new philosophy, a new way of traveling.
New strategies, new ideas, we have to think outside the box and come up with an alternative that is more satisfying than the current status quo.

I personally travel for food and wine because even if there are good foreign restaurants in my city they will never truly be like those in their native country because the food is grown differently and the experience is usually quite different for good or bad. There's also plenty of wineries or distilleries I like to visit to try things I can't get back home and learn more about them for my own curiosities. They're also usually in places with better weather then what I usually get so it acts as a nice escape.

But yeah if you don't give a shit about the hassles of going cross-continent don't bother traveling if there's not a big enough reason to leave your country.

Half of your complaints can be mitigated with a travel card and utilization of an airline points system. The rest of your complaints are straight up picking bad places to go at the wrong time.

>>2368859
so what I and many other avid travelers do is get a good travel card and funnel all your monthly expenses through it (paying off the balance every month ofc). you rack up points like crazy this way. also, pick one airline and stick to it, don't just click the lowest fare you find off Kayak or Expedia because you'll end up on some shit ass airline like Frontier or Spirit and those motherfuckers ding for every little thing so in the end you're saving maybe $100 and getting dogshit service and accommodation. I like Delta myself, Comfort + seating is the best bang for your buck in terms of comfiness and price. Another tip is to never check any bags, unless you are going to be gone for more than two weeks you can get away with a carry-on and small backpack if you pack right. No checked bags and TSA Pre/Global Entry means you can realistically show up maybe an hour before boarding and still have enough time for a beer in the lounge instead of the 3 fucking hours that everyone else ends up doing.

It's absolutely beautiful, both towns I visited. There's like zero tourists. The people are extremely kind and talkative. Place I've wanted to go for a long time, but haven't really had the chance until recently.
>What were your major dislikes?
Lots of drunk natives (similar to what you'd see in Alaska and northern Canada). It is extremely expensive. Every aspect of the trip was more expensive than what I'm used to in NA/EU (planes, food, hotels, transit). The only local food is seafood, if you don't seafood, you're shit out of luck. Everything else is expensive cupboard or frozen food.
>Do you see yourself ever going back?
Probably not, unless (future) wife or friends want to.

posts.com:
>>2367619
Did a ton of walking. Walked all of Kangerlussuaq in my 4 hour layover there, and walked all of Nuuk in my 2 weeks there. The Nuuk "metro" area is made up of like 3 sub-cities with a bus system connecting them. Assuming whether is permitting (it rained or snowed every other day), there are ample sidewalks and trails to go just about everywhere.
The locals seemed to frown on people leaving the city and exploring outside of the city. Maybe they're tired of tourists getting themselves in trouble or whatever.
There are also ferries that stop off at random villages that you can use to explore, though they weren't running while I was there.
>>2367699
Did not see it in my time in Nuuk (though there isn't much light pollution, and def far enough north, so it seems possible). Seen them numerous times in Alaska, and you're right, most of the time it's just a haze of one color, typically green, purple, yellow/orange. Very rarely do they dance like you see in timelapse videos or whatever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2367659
Touched on in my previous posts a bit already, but:
>logistics
>How easy was it to get there and back?
As far as I can tel, the only way to get to Greenland is via either Keflavik, Iceland (Reykjavik's airport), or Copenhagen via Air Greenland's A330 passenger jet.
I did see one plane with a with a Canadian livery, so presumably they fly to Kangerlussuaq from somewhere in Nunavut.
>What about getting around?
Public transit (ie busses) only exist in Nuuk it seems. Walking, biking, snowmachining, 4 wheelers, and cars are the primary forms of travel. Nuuk also had taxis, and Kangerlussuaq had a shuttle operating between the airport and town center.
>Was it easy to book a place to stay?
My experience might be unique, but the my hotel's website wasn't working and I was forced to call and email with the hotel's front desk. The 2 or 3 other hotels seemed to operate the same. So, not terrible, but not ideal.
>How was the internet and did you shitpost on a 4chan board with flags?
Internet was exceptional. Wifi in my room hovered around the 100-200mb mark for down, and like 75 for up. Genuinely impressed with the internet and cell service infrastructure they have there. Our Danish friends must be helping out. And yes, I did. Every niche place I go I always make time to post from >flag

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been to Ilulissat and Nuuk

>>2367476
I agree. if you like cold desolate places and have deep pockets Greenland is exceptional.

Getting there is difficult - I ended up going Edinburgh -> Faroe Islands (!) -> Reykjavik -> Ilulissat with internal shuttle to Nuuk. This is probably why it isn't crammed with tourists.

Svalbard is another place to consider. Flights are better. Next place on the list is the Antarctic...

>>2367699
Aurora is normally a bit disappointing. The bright green pictures are long exposures. In real life it is usually a faint diffuse green glow. If it happens to be very strong then the entire sky comes alive and it does look like the photos you've seen. This is down to chance. If you get a strong display you'll never forget it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369754
>Where should I go if I only want to stay in one destination?
The two most popular towns (with some level of infrastructure) seem to be either Nuuk or Ilulissat, as the other poster mentioned having visited. I would give edge to Nuuk only because it seems like there's a lot of ferries that can get you to a lot of the nearby towns on the coast.
>how do i even get there
Either via Copenhagen (Air Greenland), or Reykjavik, Iceland (Air Greenland and I think Iceland Air flies there). Might be able to jump on a small plane out of Nunavut, Canada, but it seems niche and not a lot of information online.
>during what months?
I went in early October, and while it was snowing most days I was there (with it staying on the ground), it wasn't oppressive by any means. So I would say as late as October or maaaybe early November, if you want to avoid oppressive winter. Not sure about how early, but maybe June, July?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370454
Kuwait City is surprisingly nice for a couple days.
Stay at the Courtyard Marriott downtown (recently renovated, best value). and plan visits to the old souq, the grand mosque, palace cultural centers, try to book a tour of the Arab Fund building (it's spectacular). Spend your evenings by the water at Lebanese restaurants at Souq Sharq marina with shisha and live music. Do not be tempted to stay at the Four Seasons, it's the worst 4S in the world. Go to restaurants and cafes in Shuwaikh Industrial and see how young locals do nightlife. It's a dry country but there are venues like House of X (bowling) that mimic a nightclub-style environment. Don't be afraid to strike conversation with the locals and tell them you're visiting their country. They are all friendly and warm to you but probably wont remember or care about you after you leave. Maybe you'll get invited somewhere cool (party yachts and condo/chalet parties are kino, none of the social media influencer bullshit either because everyone needs to keep it a secret). You can coom inside indian expats if you are into mid-late 20s pajeetas.
And as usual there are many opulent indoor malls, desert sports, water sports, vast outdoor shopping and leisure complexes and parks. Rent a car and drive across the causeway into the desert, drive along the highway of death, drive down the highway to go see massive oil refining infrastructure. Lots of driving and traffic.

posts.com:
I spent the last three months living in Cape Town, South Africa.

It's hands down the most beautiful city I've been to in my entire life. Table Mountain is a crazy scenic backdrop for urban life, and there's a beach with great surfing about 20-30 minutes away from the downtown area (CBD).

I highly recommend driving out to Kirstenbosch (sp). It's one of the nicest parks I've been to. Beautiful garden with a mountain looming over it. I felt like I was in Eden.

Income inequality is insane there, though. The nice areas are really nice but the dangerous areas are super fucking dangerous and you should not fuck around because you will end up in a dangerous situation. When I was there a lady got kidnapped in broad daylight. Thugs pulled her out of her sports car and blocked her in (https://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/western-cape/watch-woman-kidnapped-in-broad-daylight-in-cape-town-from-her-yellow-audi-r8-0ee47c81-be7b-4d69-a363-79415c2f03e8)

I had a great time and would definitely live there if I could. I stayed in the Cartwright Building on Adderley Street and had top floor panoramic views of the city for about $70 USD a night.

Racial tensions are still pretty high there. I talked to a lot of people and got the feeling that there was an uneasy peace between all the races. I never encountered any racism from anyone and overall the people there were pretty friendly and fun to be around.

Also, the Garden Route is a beautiful drive that rivals Big Sur, California.

Sorry but idk shit about Orania.

posts.com:
>>2361910

Totally legal, no one cares, US citizens can travel to Cuba under the "Support for the Cuba People" exemption. I'm a white American, went in May, zero issues in customs.

I stayed at a Casa. Basically a private apartment with a host family. They can be very helpful as even routine tasks (like getting internet for example) can be overly complicated.

For example take currency. Cuba used to have two currencies but now it's just one. The official bank exchange rate is 25-1 pesos to dollar, but on the street it's easily worth 100-1. People would buy up Euros & CAD the most, but also USD, Yen, Mexico Pesos. Cubans don't trust their currency so there's a large black market for it.

Since I had a host family they could convert the cash without worry of being ripped off in the street (lower rates, maybe even giving you old bills of Cubas defunct second currency).

In Havana, Old Town gets all the hype but Vedado is where you get away from the touts and tourists.

A big highlight was the Fábrica de arte Cubano, an old cigar factory turned into a multi level art space, entertainment venue, and club. Right on the edge before Miramar.

If you have time, Trinidad is another popular town to visit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I also went recently, specifically July. Also stayed in a Casa Particular in La Vibora. Departed from Miami, arrived in Havana via American Airlines. On the way out, said the script to the customs/border agent ie "I traveled to support the Cuba people. I stayed at a Casa Particular and I did not do commerce with any government or military entity.

>>2362317
Agree with everything in this post.

Also, taxis are pretty cheap, but like always, make sure you establish price ahead of time (and it helps to have your host clarify price too). Also, if you're in a high traffic area, you can wait a couple taxis and take a museum piece of a old Chevy or Ford, pretty awesome. But, I suggest walking if you can, especially through the more residential areas of the city, you'll get to see how locals live.

A couple other bullet points:
1. Both bottled water and toilet paper are sometimes hard to find (my host provided both, but not all do)
2. As far as I can tell there are 3 types of grocery stores:
- The first is a ratio store, and in general, only ratio books are accepted as "payment". You are not able to "purchase" items from these stores.
- The second is a general store that accepts pesos. These stores have pretty bad selection, and are a reflection of the command economy that Cuba largely has. I recall tomato sauce, vinegar, orange and lemon extract, and a type of wine basically dominating the entire store. Just vast quantities of like 5 items.
- The third store is also a general store, but it only appears to foreign currency (specifically dollars or euros). The selection at these stores are similar to what you'd find in a small grocery store in a western country. Hell, even western brands like Tide detergent and Axe body spray were available. Prices are high though. Clearly used to extract foreign currency.
3. There's not much wiggle room with police. If they ask you do to do something, just do it. Do not attempt to find a middle ground or convince them "it's ok".

I post this in like every vegas thread, but here we go again. I visit like 4 times a year to visit my best friend who has lived in vegas for 20 years. Here is my guide.

For food, we almost always do asian food. West Spring Mountain BLVD has some of the best asian food in the US. Hachi, Ichiza, Ramen Sora, Tatsu, Viet Noodle House are all fucking insanely good. And it's off the strip, so the prices are actually really good.

For shit to do, go to Red Rock. Park at Calico Basin for free. Climb the rocks to the top. It'll be the best thing you do in vegas.

DONT stay at Circus Circus, NYNY, Excalibur, Oyo, the strat, the orleans, or pretty much any hotel on West Tropicana Ave.

We usually stay at Planet Hollywood. For some reason, they always have good deals. The rooms are nice and the mall downstairs has good food. The only downside is that parking is pretty far, at least a mile each way from the rooms to the parking garage.

Definitely go downtown at night and check out Fremont Street. It's fucking wild, especially on the weekends. There are always several free bands playing outside at night.

If you're into skateboarding, bring a board and go check out the free skateparks around town. There are like a dozen of them. Some are open all night.

Arizona Hotsprings is an awesome hike into a slot canyon to see some hot springs you can bath in. You can hike all the way to the colorado river. We saw big horn sheep last time we did it.

Don't go to the strip for hookers. Go to an asian massage parlor on Spring Mountain and get jerked off. $40 for the massage, $50 tip for the handjob. Don't exchange any bodily fluids with any working girls in vegas or you'll catch something.

For picking up drunk sluts, go downtown and hang at the casino bars.

I will mention three countries-- Albania, Bosnia, and Serbia. The Muslims in Albania and Bosnia don't do Christmas, so it's just a normal weekend. The Orthodox Christians in Serbia don't do Christmas until early January, so it's not the weekend before Christmas for them.
